description: Late Middle English garbage (“the offal of a fowl, giblets, kitchen waste”, originally “refuse, what is purged away”), from Anglo-Norman, from Old French garber (“to refine, make neat or clean”), of Germanic origin, from Frankish *garwijan (“to make ready”).
Akin to Old High German garawan (“to prepare, make ready”), Old English ġearwian (“to make ready, adorn”). More at garb, yare, gear

entries.meaning: Food waste material of any kind.
Useless or disposable material; waste material of any kind.
examples: The garbage truck collects all residential municipal waste.

entries.meaning: A place or receptacle for waste material.
examples: He threw the newspaper into the garbage.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The bowels of an animal; refuse parts of flesh; offal.
(sports, slang, Canada, US, attributive) An easy shot.

verbs.description: garbage (third-person singular simple present garbages, present participle garbaging, simple past and past participle garbaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly US, Canada, obsolete) to eviscerate
examples: I have bought at Boston a dozen Pidgeons ready pulled and garbidged for three pence.
